H0.text: Bacteria are the most diverse organisms on Earth, often classified by shape or how they react to gram stain.

H1.text: Cultures are the most diverse organisms on Earth, often classified by shape or how they react to gram stain.

H2.text: Pathogens are the most diverse organisms on earth, often classified by shape or how they react to gram stain.

H3.text: Algae are the most diverse organisms on earth, often classified by shape or how they react to gram stain.

A4.text: Most bacteria can be classified as belonging to one of four groups (Gram-positive cocci, Gram-positive bacilli, Gram-negative cocci and Gram-negative bacilli).

A5.text: Based on some estimates, more than 43,000 species of bacteria have been described, but attempts to estimate the true number of bacterial diversity have ranged from 10^7 to 10^9 total species.
